code-trap-story.text: New Feature Request. A new feature lands on your desk. The junior instinct is powerful—open the IDE, start typing, figure it out as you go. But this is a trap that costs days of rework.
Junior Starts Coding. The junior approach: read the ticket, open the IDE, start coding immediately. It feels productive! But halfway through, you realize your approach won't work.
Hit a Wall. Problems emerge. Edge cases you didn't consider. Architecture that doesn't fit. You start over, then start over again. Days pass in this cycle of discovery and rework.
Senior Thinks First. The senior approach is different. Before touching code, they ask clarifying questions, draw the data flow, and identify edge cases on paper. This feels slower—but it's not.
Senior Plans on Paper. The senior writes their approach in plain English, gets quick feedback from the team, and catches problems when they're cheap to fix—before any code exists.
Code Once, Done Right. When the senior finally codes, they code once and code right. No rework cycles. Smooth code reviews. Half the total time, better results. This is the architect's way.

workflow-story.text: Step 1: Clarify. What EXACTLY is the requirement? Spend thirty minutes asking questions. What's in scope? What's not included? What are the success criteria? Vague requirements equal wasted work.
Step 2: Diagram. Spend an hour drawing. Data flow: what data goes where? Component diagram: what pieces are involved? Sequence diagram: what happens in what order? Make the invisible visible.

Step 3: Edge Cases. Thirty minutes on what could go wrong. Invalid input? External service failures? User does something unexpected? Race conditions? Finding these on paper is free—finding them in code is expensive.
Step 4: Approach Doc. Write it out in plain English. What's your plan? What key decisions did you make and why? What are the risks and how will you mitigate them? This becomes your north star.

Step 5: Quick Review. Fifteen minutes with a senior. Show them your plan, get feedback BEFORE you code. Their experience catches problems you can't see yet. This is the cheapest feedback you'll ever get.

2.5 Hours That Save Days. Total investment: about two and a half hours. This 'wastes' half a day, but saves you three to five days of rework. You spend less total time AND produce better code. That's the architect's advantage.

ai-power-story.text: The AI Secret. Here's the secret that separates those who leverage AI from those who don't: AI is amazing at coding but terrible at design. It needs YOU to do the thinking.
Vague Prompts, Vague Code. Give AI a vague request like 'write code to handle payments' and you get generic code. It misses edge cases, doesn't fit your architecture, and needs heavy rework.
Design Docs = Perfect Prompts. But give AI your design doc with sequence diagrams, edge cases, and your patterns? It generates exactly what you need. Your design work becomes the ultimate AI prompt.

You: The Architect. In this workflow, YOU are the architect. You clarify requirements, draw diagrams, identify edge cases, and write the approach. This is the creative, strategic thinking AI can't do.
AI: The Builder. AI becomes your builder—executing your vision with speed and precision. You give it clear context, it generates code, you review and refine. Human strategy, machine execution.

The Superpower. The result? Senior-level output in junior-level time. You're not just coding faster—you're thinking better. Design-first plus AI equals genuine superpowers. This is the future of software development.
